text.text:
Global Cooperation in the Raw Materials Sector –
How to secure access to critical minerals in the face of global turmoil
Based on the Paris climate agreement, several countries have set ambitious targets, trying to decarbonise
their economies. Accordingly, the transition from a linear industry dependent on oil, gas, and coal, to a circular
economy is ongoing and will usher in the era of metals. Consequently, the demand for certain metals and
minerals has already increased and will increase even more, as they are critical to wind turbines, solar panels,
some forms of hydrogen-electrolysis, and EV batteries. Currently, Europe consumes 27% of global supply of
critical raw materials, while only mining an estimated 3% of its needs, with a projected global demand increasing
by as much as 500% by 2050, according to the World Bank.
Meanwhile, the European Union has backed up its strategic interests with the Critical Raw Materials Act (CRM
Act). According to the European Commission, the CRM Act will ensure the EU access to a secure and sustainable
supply of critical resources, enabling them to meet the climate objectives set. In complement to this,
the German government has also realigned its raw materials strategy. It is supporting the efforts of German
companies to secure raw materials by promoting raw materials projects in Germany, intensifying international
partnerships, and boosting recycling and the circular economy.
Current challenges in the supply with raw materials
Nevertheless, the EU is facing an almost forgotten challenge due to an ever-increasing globalization: geopolitics
and geoeconomics. Political turbulence around the world puts supply chains under severe pressure, as
demonstrated by armed attacks on container ships or the increasing geopolitical tensions in the Indo-Pacific.
Given its industrial foundation and export-oriented economy, especially Germany is not just reliant on reduced
trade barriers, free markets, and secure trade routes. It is also particularly dependent on industrial raw material
imports, such as metals and rare earth elements. However, according to the German Raw Materials Agency
(DERA), 46% of all investigated raw materials are under procurement risk around the world.1 Furthermore,
many raw materials that are critical to Germany’s and Europe’s energy transition are extracted and especially
processed in only a few countries. Germany, for instance, imports roughly 85% of its demand for scandium, a
rare-earth material that is used for batteries or electrolysis, from China.2 The potential impact was felt at the
end of 2023, when China tightened its export restrictions on technologies for the extraction and processing of
rare earths.3
Another obstacle for the current raw materials policy is the downstream-oriented approach. Simply promoting
the production of photovoltaic modules, for example, without considering their supply and process chain does
not yet reduce strategic dependencies. As the new photovoltaic strategy shows, the German government is
aware of this challenge.4 Yet, future policies need to take these considerations into account and apply them to
further value chains of critical green technologies. On top of that, the capital that is provided by the EU or the
German government is not yet sufficient to compete with the international realities of financing complex mining
projects or investing in processing facilities. With the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), the Biden administration
has, e.g., issued a set of policies that incentivise investments in critical mineral processing, manufacturing,
and recycling. The Department of Energy, for example, is allocated $40 billion in loan authority, supported by
$3.6 billion in credit subsidies for loan guarantees. This funding can be directed towards various initiatives,
including to “critical minerals processing, manufacturing, and recycling”5.
Additionally, bureaucratic obstacles for mining projects in the EU persist. Several critical raw materials could
be mined within European borders. However, it takes up to 15 years from the first geological assessment to
the start of mining within the European Union. Moreover, most Europeans associate the mining sector with
problematic environmental and social consequences, as they have not experienced domestic mining for several
decades. This should be addressed by policymakers as well as business players.
1 DERA-Rohstoffliste 2023 (DERA, 2023)
2 Abhängigkeit der deutschen Wirtschaft von China: Bei einzelnen Produkten kritisch (Institut für Weltwirtschaft in Kiel, 2023)
3 Rohstoff-Trends Q4/2023 (DERA, 2024)
4 Photovoltaik-Strategie: Handlungsfelder und Maßnahmen für einen beschleunigten Ausbau der Photovoltaik (BMWK, 2023)
5 Building a clean energy economy: A guidebook to the Inflation Reduction Act’s investments in clean energy and climate action (The White House, 2023)
Recommendations on how to secure resilient and sustainable access to critical minerals.
To remain globally competitive, the EU and Germany need to implement a set of policies alongside the CRM
Act to tackle looming de-industrialisation by incentivising the uptake of minerals. As challenges to resilient
and sustainable access to critical minerals add up, we, as Rio Tinto, would like to suggest the following
possible solutions to the challenges at stake.
1) Increasingly link public raw material partnerships with industry.
German industrial companies rely on global trade and market access. Given their reliance on imports from
third-countries, policymakers are trying to tackle this issue by strengthening or initiating raw material partnerships.
Rio Tinto believes that free trade, combined with partnerships founded on the highest ESG-standards
that are moulded into a comprehensible and mutually profitable contract with countries that have the raw and
processed materials in question, is essential for Europe. In addition to these country-level partnerships, it is
imperative to involve companies with mining and processing expertise. Rio Tinto underscores the importance
of incorporating practical industry knowledge in the negotiations of raw material partnerships at the state level.
This approach enhances efficiency and opens avenues for exploring potential cooperation at industry level.
2) Promote offtake agreements between private players.
The present global landscape, marked by its unpredictable geopolitical dynamics, mirrors the high volatility
observed in the raw materials markets and their prices. To ensure a resilient and sustainable supply of critical
minerals, especially for technologies essential to meeting carbon reduction goals, it is imperative to encourage
and promote offtake agreements among private entities. This enables price stability for buyers and provides
planning certainty for mine operators. Both the EU Commission and the German government can promote
these offtake agreements by uniting and endorsing diverse stakeholders. We, as Rio Tinto, stand prepared to
collaborate with different entities across the value and process chains.
3) Long-term financing along the entire value and process chain is key.
Diversifying supply sources and raising ESG standards are important for enhancing the strategic autonomy of
both the European and German economies. While diversification may initially entail higher costs for exploring
and extracting new raw material deposits, we endorse the establishment of a German raw materials fund. We
suggest including a diverse range of eligible companies and projects, as well as sufficient funding. In addition,
we emphasize the need for longer-term, targeted support for production expansion and investment in Europe
and abroad, covering the entire value and process chain from exploration to processing and recycling.
4) Support European processing capacities.
The European and German raw material strategies should address an industrial policy framework for future
value creation within the EU, with a particular focus on the processing of raw materials. While the CRM Act
introduces quotas, it is to recognize that a one-size-fits-all approach may not be optimal. Certain raw materials
already have a reasonable degree of diversification, while others are predominantly sourced, processed, and
recycled in other countries, making diversification almost impossible with the current level of knowledge. Targets
and quotas should be linked to concrete incentive programs to build up European capacities at an economically
justifiable price. The same applies to recycling capacities, for which the financing of private investment
in research and development is essential.
Our way forward: Engaging in dialogue.
By finding better ways to provide the materials the world needs, Rio Tinto is leading the way to a more sustainable
economy. We are keen to support the German government with our 150 years of experience in mining.
As an Anglo-Australian company and the second largest mining company in the world, Rio Tinto is already
significantly contributing to the EU’s and Germany’s strategic ambitions to become more autonomous by diversifying
raw material sourcing globally. We want to become a driving force for more investment in the European
mining sector and more global cooperation. That is why we would like to engage with you and look
forward to a constructive dialogue to discuss our improvements to the outlined challenges.
Contact:
Jonathan Vanherberghen
Director External Affairs Europe
2-4 Schuman Roundabout, Level 5, 1040 Brussel
T: +32 488 38 30 19 – E: J.Vanherberghen@riotinto.com
